title: Coast Guard Suspends Search for California Boat Fire Victims
text:
SANTA BARBARA, Calif.—The search for survivors from a diving boat that burned and sank Monday morning off the coast of California has been called off, Coast Guard officials said.

Thirty-four people who were trapped aboard the Conception when it caught fire near Santa Cruz Island in Santa Barbara County are presumed dead, making it one of the worst U.S. maritime disasters in recent years.

Twenty bodies—11 female and nine male—have been recovered, and divers spotted another four to six pinned in the wreckage, Santa Barbara County Sheriff Bill Brown said.

Local law-enforcement and fire officials gather in Santa Barbara, Calif., on Sept. 3 near the site of a fire that consumed a recreational diving boat. Photo: Christian Monterrosa/Associated Press

The boat fire, the cause of which hasn’t been determined, broke out while the passengers were sleeping below deck. Both the stairwell and escape hatch appear to have been blocked by the hot flames, Sheriff Brown said.

Five crew members, including the captain, whose quarters were higher up on the third deck, were able to escape the inferno, he added.

A sixth crew member, the cook, slept downstairs, according to Broc Johnson, who went on three diving trips on the Conception in the past three years, including one just two months ago. Authorities confirmed that one crew member perished in the fire.

“I loved that boat; I loved the crew; I loved that operation,” Mr. Johnson, a contractor and dive master, said. “I’m shocked.”

U.S. Coast Guard Capt. Monica Rochester said rescuers didn’t see any further signs of distress or debris during a 24-hour-long search, indicating there aren’t any remaining survivors. She added that the Conception had passed its most recent inspection for fire-safety equipment, which includes fire extinguishers.

The first distress call from the ship went out just before 3:30 a.m. Monday, and was picked up by the Coast Guard. The Conception was moored near Platt’s Harbor on the northern side of Santa Cruz Island, a popular destination for divers that is part of the Channel Islands National Park about 25 miles south of Santa Barbara.

“Mayday! Mayday! Mayday! Conception. Platt’s Harbor, north side, Santa Cruz,” a man can be heard saying.

“Vessel in distress, this is the Coast Guard sector Los Angeles,” another man responded. “What is your position and number of persons on board, over?”

The distressed caller replied in a garbled transmission with what appear to be coordinates, then said, “I can’t breathe.”

The five crew members who escaped the flames got into a dinghy, and paddled to a nearby fishing boat. Shirley and Bob Hansen, the boat’s owners, helped them on board. One of the crew appeared to have a badly broken leg, Ms. Hansen said.

One of the men told the Hansens that he had heard a noise and gotten up. When he opened the door to the galley, he saw an orange glow, Ms. Hansen said. When he tried to get down to the deck, the flames stopped him, and he saw things falling from the ceiling.

“It looked like the whole boat from the bow to the stern was engulfed in flames,” Ms. Hansen said.

Because the bodies recovered from the wreckage were badly burned, investigators will use DNA analysis to identify the deceased, said Sheriff Brown. Officials used the same method to identify those who died in the 2018 Camp Fire in Northern California.

Two high-school students from a public charter school in Santa Cruz called Pacific Collegiate School were on board with two parents, school officials said Tuesday.

At the Santa Barbara Harbor, where the Conception was scheduled to return before the fire, a small memorial had popped up Tuesday, with dozens of flowers and candles, as well as messages to some of the victims. One framed photo, showing a picture of a man with his arm around a woman, said, “I love you Allie—and you know I always will! I’ll miss you forever. [Heart] Rob.”

Another message, written on a red and white flag, said, “We’ll remember you on every dive.”

Christine Diaz, who has lived in the area for more than 30 years, said she knew the Conception well, though she wasn’t sure if she knew anyone who was on the ship. She worked out of the harbor for eight years on a whale watching boat.

“It’s a sad day for all of us here in Santa Barbara,” Ms. Diaz, 55 years old, said. “I just stopped by to see what was going on, just say a prayer for those families.”

She said the setup of the Conception, with the crew sleeping higher up than passengers, was typical of commercial boats in the area.

“If there was any issue, they would do their best to provide assistance,” she said. “If they couldn’t, I can assure you their option was to save themselves.”

Kristy Finstad, co-owner of the dive company that chartered the boat for a trip to the Channel Islands, was on board Monday and is presumed dead, her stepfather, Al Harmeling, said. She ran Santa Cruz-based Worldwide Diving Adventures with her husband, Dan Chua, who was leading an expedition elsewhere Monday.

Nicknamed “Fin” when she was younger, Ms. Finstad always had an affinity for the water and studied marine biology. About five years ago, she and her husband set out in a catamaran from Baja, Mexico, for the islands of the South Pacific. They visited New Zealand, Fiji and other islands, trading fish they caught for vegetables and leading diving excursions. They returned to the states last fall and bought a home near Lake Tahoe.

Ms. Finstad’s mother, Rita Harmeling, said her daughter loved that “different world under the water, where it’s quiet except the noise of your breathing.”

—Jimmy Vielkind contributed to this article.

Write to Zusha Elinson at zusha.elinson@wsj.com, Ian Lovett at Ian.Lovett@wsj.com and Erin Ailworth at Erin.Ailworth@wsj.com
description: The search for survivors from a diving boat that burned and sank off the coast of California has been called off. Thirty-four people who were trapped aboard the vessel are presumed dead.
